I recently used Omari for YouTube promotions. I'll preface this by saying that I don't think it's an absolutely terrible company as they will get you some form of results, and for music hobbyists that's better than nothing. However, serious customers should know what to expect when paying for expensive promotional packages and after having experience with OmariMC I feel there are both cheaper and more effective alternatives. I paid for Omari's YouTube promotion that estimated between 11,000 and 77,000 views. At the end of the promotion my song received less than 6,000 views from Omari's advertising, a painful underperformance for a high price tag. From the Omari promo I also saw that huge chunks of my views were coming from non-english speaking countries, which resulted in poor engagement numbers, high dislikes, and bad YouTube analytic data. I raised several questions with the company via email during the course of the promotion, and received relatively quick answers and temporary boosts to the results, but said results only lasted 3-4 days, not the duration of the campaign. Many of the days that my ad should've been running I received 0 views, and when I complained about my results I'd get a short boost of approximately 1,000 views from India or Italy over the course of an hour or two. After my promo package was up I decided to run my own YouTube ad, which wasn't very difficult to figure out, and received a much better subscriber-to-view ratio and like-to-view ratio for an affordable cost-per-view(approximately $0.04.) To give some context, before I ran my own ad my video had accumulated 6,500 views, 30 likes, and 9 dislikes from the Omari promo. When I created my own ad I reached 8,000 views, 65 likes, and kept my dislike count at 9. Omari sells itself as having specialized knowledge on how to run ads for genre specific music, but it needs to be said that this specialized marketing resulted in a worse overall performance than an ad I created with no previous experience with the YouTube ads platform. I've managed to offset the poor engagement I received from the Omari promo, but I'm sad that my music video had to receive all this bad, spammy data in the first place, simply because the targeting was recklessly created by OmariMC. I want to like Omari because I believe accessible music marketing companies are one of the most important tools an indie artist can have, but until their services become less sloppy, then I cannot in good faith recommend them.

review_title: Terrible customer service - Try these companies instead!
review_content: Terrible customer service.  Probably the worst I have ever dealt with. We recently submitted a song to OmariMC and received a message that since we used the word “damn”, they could not accept it. That was fine, although “damn” on its own is not considered an explicit lyric on all platforms in the industry. They agreed to a refund, but said there would be a fee for Palpal. I expressed that was unacceptable since it was misleading on the website. I researched prior to submitting to make sure “damn” was not explicit. After some back and forth and explaining this to them, it remained the same. Honestly you should go with a company with great customer service. Try Indie Music Academy. They have been so in-depth and have really taken care of us as customers. Their services are wonderful, and their customer service is amazing. Two other wonderful companies way more worth your money is Planetary Group (PR and playlisting as well) and Starlight PR.You’ll see their reply below, but it still does not address these concerns. What I told them is that their website is misleading. Explicit content when it comes to music is very specific. It is not out of the ordinary to assume “no explicit content” means exactly what those standards would be, especially a from a company that is pitching music to the industry that has those exact standards. In addition, the word “damn”, among other words commonly used in the English language, is not always considered a “curse” word (I.e. why the music industry does not consider it explicit content).  I also told them, I recommend that they update their website to inform their customers that their ideas of “explicit content” does not line up with the “explicit content” by music industry standards, and then go into detail what those differences are (I.e. the word “damn” not being allowed). Only then will I believe they are being fair to their customers and not misleading them. If they choose not to do this, and continue to mislead their customers, it is extremely bad form to not give a full refund when a customer decided not to use their service due to this misleading information.

I enlisted Omari on a trial basis to determine how legit their playlist pitch service is when it comes to spotify. The company claims that it will pitch your song to x number of playlists with no guarantee as to how many will add your song and no guarantee of how many spins it will get. This is both true and false. X, of course, is determined by how much you pay for the service. More pay for the promo, more playlists they pitch to. Makes business sense, especially the way they do it.Omari will get you some spins. Those spins will be based on how much you pay. But the algorithm to locate your song for anyone searching for similar music will be screwed. Omari clearly has a group of playlists that they place your song in and when the campaign expires, all of the playlists drop it that day. That was the final clue I needed to determine that I will not use the service again. Other clues were the playlists that my song ended up in. A number of them made no sense for the song's subject matter or genre. (Sad country song about spending the last bit of time with a father figure finding its way into a Forest Gump Soundtrack playlist)(at least try to hide it...)Moral of the story: you will get some spins. They don't mean anything. review_title: Sketchy (probably fake) Results, terrible customer support
review_content: It started with me requesting a silver YouTube campaign, with a rush (which is what I normally ask for). I got the confirmation that the order was processed a day later, and I was expecting to start seeing my views increase 1-2 days later. After 4 days, I still hadn't seen any results whatsoever. The views I got on the video were very low. I emailed support, and Taylor responded, saying that the ad was moving to a crawl, and he changed some of the configurations on the promo. He told me I should start seeing results within a day, but to email him 3 days later if I still hadn't seen any change. 3 days later, there's no change. I email him again. This time, he punts me to Jaron, their marketing manager. 7 hours later, I get this from Jaron: "Hi, I have made adjustments for your campaign. Talk soon, Jaron". That's it, no details as to what went wrong, no apology, no insight as to when things should improve, or how confident he was that he actually found the problem. Seemed to me like he had no idea what to do. Turns out, I was right. I responded asking for more details. He told me my ad had "stalled" and that he increased the CPV and adjusted keywords. I responded by thanking him and asking if I could at least get a credit for the rush option I paid for, given this was a week and a half after I placed the initial request, and the campaign should already be done by now. Furthermore, I didn't ask for a refund, I asked them to give me a free rush on the next campaign I was going to pay for a few days later (This is a $17 value, and at this point in the year, I've used them for over $2K in promos - not exactly a demanding request). He responded by saying: "Our rush order only pertains to us replying to and accepting the promotion within 24 business hours. However, as a gesture of good faith I will honor your request". Note still no apology, or any indication that they took accountability for the problem. 4 days later, I had to email him again, saying it still wasn't fixed, I asked him if maybe the campaign wasn't placed correctly from the start. At this point, Jaron responds with: "This should allow for the campaign to run successfully. It is not always an issue of the campaign being set up correctly or incorrectly. There are a lot of varying factors when it comes to running successful campaigns as the market/competition is always evolving." He also tells me that in the two weeks since I placed the request, the number of views from their service was 75. That was his way of telling me the campaign was "working", but it needed "tweaking" (his words). Think about that. Based on this explanation, it's "normal" to see campaigns underperform so significantly. These things can happen whenever the market fluctuates. I had to monitor it myself and contact support so that Omari would look at it. That means that if you pay for a campaign, you could get the thousands of views they promise you, or you could get 75... and if YOU don't notice it, or if you're running multiple promo campaigns and don't see that the Omari campaign isn't working, they won't do anything about it pro-actively. So you can't trust their service. What happened next was very interesting. Within the span of 60 minutes, the video got 2200-2300 views in one shot, and then it completely stopped. What's even weirder is that out of those views, I didn't get a single subscriber, or even a like (or comment). I realize that the campaign doesn't guarantee subscribers. That's not my issue. I have about 800 subscribers and about 70,000 views in total since the start of my channel. That means 1 in 87.5 views generate a subscriber (on average). While the results can vary, let's simply agree that 0 subscribers on 2200 views is just not realistic. It's a clear sign of fake views. It's been 24 hours since thes 2200 views and the numbers stalled again completely. I've paid over $160 for this promo, I've gotten a fraction of the views they tell you you're getting, and I'm not getting any legitimate help from their customer support, who doesn't want to acknowledge that they screwed up somewhere. The sad part is up until now, I planned on using them as a key part of my marketing strategy when it comes to YouTube, but now, I wouldn't use them again even if it was free. Nathaniel, what's the point of doing all of this add-value stuff like publishing advice for content creators on your YouTube channel, when you can't deliver on your core products, and have a crappy support team. I thought you were smarter than that.Update: So Jaron, how do you explain the 2200 views in a single hour and then a total stop. Google ads doesn't work that way. And why is it that you still haven't fixed it... Maybe don't end your reply with "we always deliver the expected result" when it's simply not true.

There is no real quick solution to growing your followers other than the tired old grind that is the music biz so don't get your hopes too high. review_title: Spotify playlisting service is top notch, but could use some tweaking.
review_content: We have used Omari several times to promote our EDM artist from our label.  We started out using the most inexpensive package as a test to see if Omari was legit.  And we have determined that this service IS LEGIT. Listen, promoting a new artist or starting out as a new artist is hard and getting a following is even more difficult.  Omari does what he says.  He gets songs on playlists.   In our experience we have received plays, song saves and some subscribers.   We have used the service a couple of times for the same artist...  on each occasion the songs were placed on the same playlists with the same themes.. which I was not impressed by.  I was hoping for new playlists with maybe new themes to reach a new audience.  I am not saying they didnt do the job, its just the playlists themselves had a wide variety of music genres on them and that our tracks may not have fit with all of the songs on the playlist that the song was on.  Having said that, some of the smaller playlists the song appeared on were more targeted toward the dance/edm genres which offered us less plays but more targeted listeners.   The playlists are real.  The listeners are real.   That's important.  My only critique is that sometimes the songs land on massive playlists with lots of followers but there are so many songs on the playlist that getting a decent amount of plays can be hard to come by over 2-3 week period.  Just because you have playlist with 20k followers doesnt mean they are listening to every song.  Remember, lots of people use the shuffle feature so its possible that your song may not even get played to them.  Also I doubt all 20k people are listening to that playlist during that 2-3 week period.  So while this is a great service, it can be improved by more targeted playlists with fewer songs and more listeners.   Kind of hard to come by these days on Spotify.  But in the end we come back to Omari because A) His service is honest.  B) We realize that it takes awhile to build an audience for a new artist, it wont happen over night and getting lots of song saves and being playlisted on personal playlists have definitely come from Omari's promotions.  C) He does not use BOTS...  Beware of services offering 5000+ plays on your track.  Its not real.  I'd rather have 100 real listeners liking the track and putting it in their playlist and telling their friends then fake bots playing tracks to up the play count.   Spotify's algorithm wont pick up the plays and suggest the track to others because the people who are playing the tracks are fake accounts who listen to 20 different genres of music.  D) Omari is Christian...  I would rather do business with a Christian..than with someone who is lying to me. For a Christian to base his entire business around lies would mean he is not a Christian in the first place.  So we trust that he is doing the job he says he is... If he were lying then I'd say eventually the truth would be revealed.  We have used a ton of different promotional companies to promote different styles of music on Spotify.  Most are fake or yield horrible results.  Omari yields results.  Is his service expensive?  Yes.  Will you get on playlists?  Yes.  Will you get followers?  That all depends on how good your music is and if you're on the right playlist.  Will you get plays?  Yes.   Will you get song saves?   Depends on how good your music is.   Will you go viral and be the next big thing?  Probably not.  But if you look into the other promotional companies around today, they are either stealing  your money or simply cannot compete with Omari's service.   We have yet to use his services for anything other than Spotify.  So I cannot comment on his other services.  Our recommendation is that you give this service a shot.  Look at the playlists you are on.  See how many plays you get from these playlists.  Keep notes.  And judge for yourself.  If you have problems I know for certain a HUMAN will respond to your inquiry at his website.

review_title: I Ordered The $1,800 Spotify Package Twice
review_content: One of the biggest regrets of my life: I used this service twice, maxing out at the highest available payment option, for two different genres of songs (pop and hip-hop) during two different periods of time (January 2020 and July 2020). Unfortunately, both focus groups had the same results. You’ll get an initial inflation of plays, monthly listeners, and saves, however when the promotion ends and the playlist curators remove your song, your numbers will plummet to near-zero (with the exception of the quantity of plays, of course). In my experience, bots are most likely to blame for this. In my case, for both songs, the monthly listeners increased to 20K-30K and the saves increased to 1K-2K, then, almost as if someone flipped a switch, my monthly listeners and favorites plummeted to almost exactly where I was before the campaign (around 1K monthly listeners and 10-20 saves per song). Monthly listeners (and especially saves) are supposed to slowly taper, not plummet - and especially not back down to where the song was before the campaign started. Keep in mind that the 2 songs that I chose to promote aren’t pieces of trash that I whipped up in my bedroom (or else I’d expect the numbers to plummet, because who would want to listen to them?). Both songs were professionally recorded, mixed and mastered in Nashville, with a variety of songwriters attached to each song. With a mainstream-sounding pop and hip-hop song being promoted, you’d expect some type of traction with this level of Spotify promotion package from Omari. This company really needs to flush out these third-party, botted Spotify playlists. I work 60-70 hours per week to fund the making and marketing of my music, and it's a shame that I've wasted thousands of dollars here.Omari will claim that your music is expected to reach a certain threshold of plays as "proof" that their service is legitimate. However, based on my experiences with other playlist-pitching services, I can absolutely guarantee you that, if the playlists that my song was placed into were either organically grown and/or weren't bot-infested, I wouldn't have seen such a sudden drop-off in saves and a complete snapback in monthly listeners (back to exactly where I was before the promotion started) once the promotion ended. One thing I forgot to mention that put the nail in the coffin: I spotted 2 playlists that had most of their followers erased. More specifically, "Hip Hop Music" and "Chill Music 2020." Both playlists had just under 100K followers when my singles were first placed into both playlists during both promotional periods. Then, suddenly, both playlists only had around a few dozen followers. Spotify frequently wipes out playlists that are spotted to host a mass amount of fake followers. As of writing this, it looks like both playlists are back up to a little over 1,000 followers, so it looks like EDM Hits (who owns both playlists) are trying to slowly artificially pump their numbers back up. These are just 2 examples; who knows how many other playlists that my songs were placed into also had their follower-count wiped out because of artificial inflation.Also, although it wasn't necessarily a dealbreaker for me, some people might have a problem with their music being placed in playlists that don't match their genre or feeling of the song. The hip hop track that I had promoted with Omari is dark and gritty (both production and lyricism), so to have it placed in "Chill Music 2020" had me scratching my head.Source: Without disclosing too much of my personal life, I worked in marketing (more specifically, streaming marketing) at one of the major labels, so I know a thing-or-two about playlisting and how the numbers should look once a song is either removed from or shuffled around a network of (legitimate) playlists.-----Update: Refunds are not issued to customers. Omari gauges the success of campaigns solely based off of the quantity of (botted) streams. I was under the impression that Omari’s campaign would’ve generated organic playlist traffic - if I wanted botted playlist traffic, I would’ve used a different company for much cheaper.  For those who don’t know (I’ve seen many 5-star reviews come in with people not knowing what they’re talking about after purchasing Omari’s Spotify campaign), the only way to differentiate organic versus inorganic traffic for playlist placements is not by quantity of streams, but by the health of the song once the track is removed from the playlist (analyzed through Spotify’s backend metrics and manually tracking statistics pre-and-post placements). I’m extremely disappointed. Good luck to those who still choose to opt in. You’ve been warned.

review_title: Omari keeps its promises, gets results

I read a blogger’s review/ranking of 10 promotional companies and both Omari and another outfit seemed suited to having my songs added to playlists, promoted on You Tube and eventually pushed to alternative, college and public radio stations.Omari promptly responded to my first and subsequent emails. The other service responded, but not quite as quickly. I chose Omari because of its range of services, responsiveness and its prices. I felt it fit my needs.My first promotion was for three songs at the Bronze level. I staggered the releases three weeks apart with the thought that first exposure could build An audience through the third and beyond.The songs (all from my “Just Us Chickens” CD) attracted more than 2,000 listeners and are still being played. One of the songs, “Everything I Know (I Learned from Loneliness)” had 1,500 streams and is still on playlists.I followed those with a Christmas single (“In the Arms of a Song”) I thought would do well. It was streamed 650 times in just 4 days and was over 1,700 the last time I checked. It was even picked up by a playlist devoted to music for movies — a nice surprise — that’s played it 600+ times!In retrospect, I was trying to time the release to coincide with the Christmas season. The song might’ve done even better had I waited to release it two or three weeks before Christmas day, rather than Nov.15.Omari has done what it said it would do — released my music promptly and used its network of playlist operators to have it played. My only criticism (why my rating is four stars, not five) is that the majority of the playlists adding my songs seemed similar and generic. I listened to some other songs on the lists and thought my brand of music might’ve done better on lists  that placed more emphasis on lyrics and originality, and targeted a more music-savvy, sophisticated audience.But I’m pleased overall and am planning a new Omari promotion of several songs from “Pigeon Toad,” a CD with a Dec. 7 release date. I haven’t decided yet which programs I’ll buy, but I may release songs at different levels (Bronze, Gold etc.) and stagger them toward a finale of the strongest song.Longterm I don’t expect commercial success. But with Omari’s help I hope to have more  and more people enjoy my music.

review_title: Extremely low audience retention (2% at 2 minutes via ad vs 30% organic)
review_content: Don't waste money on a service that is not going to help you build a legitimate fanbase. The YouTube ads are ineffective at finding you people who are going to be interested in your content, they just do discovery ads so that it counts all the views from people who will not actually watch your video. I emailed Omari's team halfway through the ad asking if they could change the age targeting because its audience was out of my demographic. The audience was 87% ages 25-65+ and my target demographic is 13-25. I did not recieve a reply. I called after a few days of terrible audience retention and asked for the ad to be pulled so it wouldn't bring my stats down further. Omari gave me a BS response about how it's because it's not an in play ad and the view counts are counting all views whereas in play counts only if they get to 30 seconds at least, and that at 2 minutes an in play ad would have 6% retention. Ok well still way more than 2% retention on my discovery ad. Its not because it's a bad video either. A preview of the vid is getting me about 50c a follower on instagram in expensive areas primarily california. So the age targeting and most likely the rest of the targeting is just nothing close to the "highly targeted YouTube ads to have maximum engagement because we have thousands of dollars of experience" that was advertised to me. These people don't know your fanbase better than you do and at any rate you are not going to benefit from enhanced targeting from these ads vs running them yourself or finding an ads manager that will listen to your input and feedback. Omari's company will disregard your feedback, I brought up the age issue twice and zero response. Super unprofessional of them and a waste of money. They also would not elaborate on how my ad was being presented because I still have no idea. Glad I ran this as a test ad because I was considering buying much bigger packages if the service worked. I won't be purchasing again and I suggest you don't either.
